title: Graph (topology)
summary: In topology, a branch of mathematics, a graph is a topological space which arises from a usual graph G = ( E , V ) {\displaystyle G=(E,V)} by replacing vertices by points and each edge e = x y âˆˆ E {\displaystyle e=xy\in E} by a copy of the unit interval I = [ 0 , 1 ] {\displaystyle I=[0,1]} , where 0 {\displaystyle 0} is identified with the point associated to x {\displaystyle x} and 1 {\displaystyle 1} with the point associated to y {\displaystyle y} . That is, as topological spaces, graphs are exactly the simplicial 1-complexes and also exactly the one-dimensional CW complexes.[1]
